title: Transforming Scores
question_text:
A set of scores is transformed by applying the following to each of the scores:
$$\text{transformed score }= 2.6 \text{ (original score) }- 1.4$$
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

choices.text: The standard deviation of the transformed scores $= 2.6\text{ (standard deviation of the original scores)} - 1.4$
The IQR of the transformed scores $= 2.6 \text{ (IQR of the original scores)}$
The Q3 of the transformed scores $=2.6 \text{ (Q3 original score)} - 1.4$
The mean of the transformed scores $= 2.6 \text{ (mean of the original score) }- 1.4$
The median of the transformed scores $= 2.6 \text{ (median of the original score) }- 1.4$

solution:
Off the bat, we can see that Choices 'A' and 'B' discuss spread.

Multiplying each score by $2.6$ will stretch the data, therefore creating a larger spread.

However, subtracting $1.4$ from each score will shift all the scores down, which means that the spread will still remain the same. Therefore, Choice 'A' is the false statement.

Choices 'C', 'D', and 'E' discuss positions. Positions are affected by multiplication and subtraction, so all of these choices are true. Thus, we can eliminate these options.

Note: spread is affected by multiplication and division, and not addition and subtraction. Positions will be affected by all four of these operations.

An alternative approach to solving this would be to create an original data set and calculate the standard deviation, IQR, Q3, mean, and median on your calculator.

Then transform all of the data using the equation given and calculate the standard deviation, IQR, Q3, mean, and median on your calculator. Compare your answers to the choices and see which one is not true.
